title: 114_hr5218
content: The Act may be cited as the "Targeting Child Predators Act of 2016" and includes provisions for the nondisclosure of administrative subpoenas. Section 3486(a) of title 18, United States Code is amended to replace "the Secretary of the Treasury" with "the Secretary of Homeland Security", remove the phrase "ordered by a court" from paragraph (5), and introduce restrictions on disclosing information obtained through subpoenas under this section for 180 days. The federal official issuing the subpoena must certify that disclosure may endanger individuals, lead to flight from prosecution, evidence tampering, witness intimidation, or jeopardize an investigation. Recipients of the subpoena can disclose information to comply with the request or seek legal advice from an attorney. The subpoena recipient can disclose information to seek legal advice from an attorney or other permitted individuals. Recipients must adhere to nondisclosure requirements and notify others of such requirements if disclosing information subject to them. Upon request, individuals intending to disclose information must comply with the federal official's instructions. The nondisclosure requirement imposed under subparagraph (A) can be reviewed judicially and extended as per section 3486A(a)(4) if needed. Subpoenas issued under this section must include notice of the availability of judicial review for nondisclosure requirements. Judicial review is available for nondisclosure requirements under section 3486A(a)(4) and must be included in subpoenas. Judicial review of nondisclosure requirements can be requested by recipients of subpoenas under section 3486. Recipients can notify the Government or file a petition for review in court within 30 days. The Government must then apply for an order to prohibit disclosure of the subpoena's existence or contents. The subpoena recipient can request judicial review of nondisclosure requirements in the district court where they do business or where the investigation is taking place. The court should rule promptly on petitions or applications, and the nondisclosure requirement remains in effect during related proceedings. The court should rule promptly on petitions for a nondisclosure order, which must include conditions appropriate to the circumstances. An application must include a certification from the Federal official indicating potential risks if disclosure is not prohibited, such as endangering individuals, flight from prosecution, evidence tampering, witness intimidation, or jeopardizing an investigation. The court issues a nondisclosure order if disclosure may endanger individuals, lead to flight from prosecution, evidence tampering, witness intimidation, or jeopardize an investigation or trial. In cases where disclosure may pose risks, a district court can extend a nondisclosure order for up to 180 days or longer if necessary. Closed hearings are conducted to prevent unauthorized disclosure of requests for records or information under section 3486, with all related documents kept sealed as needed. The district court can extend a nondisclosure order for up to 180 days or longer to prevent unauthorized disclosure of a subpoena under section 3486. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in title 18, United States Code. "Judicial review of nondisclosure requirements under section 3486A."
